content:
Another issue with this clash is that Validator 2 is the only test case where you insert at index 0.

I just got this in fastest mode and got 100% on tests and then only 50% on validators because I missed this edge case and the 0 add 0 edge case.

It's really unsatisfying when clashes have edge cases hidden in validators. I really suggest fixing it. You can see why this clash has been receiving negative scores from clashers and had SHORTEST deactivated.. It's actually a really great clash concept, but the test cases ruin it. :(
This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "SHORTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

The final validator is 0 and x is 0, so when you add it to the value you get 00, but you are required to print this as 0.

"It is guaranteed that the number n does not contain leading zeros." is misleading here because n can be 0, which has a zero at the start but isn't "leading".

It's an annoying edge case to hide in a validator. I just got 75% too due to this. It would be better if you either had a similar test case or just removed the validator.

I did approve this contribution - but when I did shortest just now I got 100% on tests and 75% on validators. I'm not yet sure what the problem is, it has to do with my 'cheat'  to do final print with another input. Maybe make test4 test and validator identical?
I=input
I()
x=I()
o=''
C=1
for c in I():
 if x>c and C:o+=x;C=0
 o+=c
if C:o+=x
I(o)
j'aime beaucoup, simple rapide efficace

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Pretty good clash. I like the last validator case: this rewards players that pay close detail to the description.
Good exercice, not too easy but can be clear very fast

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: lgtm

I was able to pass everything except validator 4 using a flawed algorithm that inserts the number at the index of the first digit that is less than or equal to the number. Switch validator 4 and test case 4 so that someone who does this doesn't fail after passing all the test cases.

Also sheeesh 57 bytes

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It all works, and it's a nice way of playing around with numbers.

Small suggestion for statement text (but not too problematic, so I'm going to approve after this anyway): change three times 'it' for 'them' in the first sentence (I think 'it' is referring to the cards, 'them' would be more clear).
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Please stop telling a story.
When I am playing a clash I want to go straight to the important values and start coding. I don't want to know about sam's nightmare. I like clashes starting like: "You are given...and you should return..."

Goal section
* Please change {[7}} to {{7}}.

Stub generator
* Line 2: d or x?

Cases
* Test 4: n = 0 <= n is NOT a positive integer.

Thanks.

Nice one! I started with the idea 'this is very easy', but along the test cases I ran into some things I did not think of before, so that's a good sign.

- Statement: closing parenthesis is missing "(Including beginning and end of [[n]]."
- Last sentence statement: {[7}} should become {{7}}
- Stub generator: at this moment you let s be int, and the other two strings. You can them also all be integers, and leave the work to the player to turn it into strings for inserting etc.

Modified.
Also I don't think n can be integer..?
Modified

The point of clash of code and coding in general is to apply it to real world situations. Giving a situation is how things happen normally in the real world. Part of all coding problems as well is deciding what information is relevant to the problem and how you could use that information. If you want things handed to you on a silver platter, go follow a step by step tutorial on something.
Modified.
Modified.

It's because the final validator is 0 and x is 0, so when you add it to the value you get 00, but you are required to print this as 0.

"It is guaranteed that the number n does not contain leading zeros." is misleading here because n can be 0, which has a zero at the start but isn't "leading".

It's an annoying edge case to hide in a validator tbh. I just got 75% too due to this.

I kinda get what you mean, but I don't think "It is guaranteed that the number n does not contain leading zeros." is misleading at all? I'm pretty most people (I won't say everyone but well you have the internet to search for it) know that 0 itself isn't a leading zero. I included this since the input is read as a string format. There might be some players taking all their time just to prevent a case with leading zero. The word "non-negative interger" indicates that 0 is included as well. 

Below there someone mentioned that this require players to "pay close attention to the description".  I think here is the place where careful coders and people that doesn't cover all cases differs, and those who covered it are rewarded with 100%.

But anyway thanks for giving me this feedback ty.
I agree personally. A bit of story is ok, but the statement should be at least 60% content, when it is 50+% story, it's annoying and frustrating, especially in fastest mode.

I think coding is the ability of take any problem and convert it into programming language (You can disagree with me it's fine everyone has different opinion). In this problem you need to identify the task you need to do (which is, guess what, Insert to Maximum). Unless you actually just code for fun at a beginner level, you won't progress further / Solve real life problem if you only favor too straight forward statement.

I'm also pretty sure I deleted a lot of unnecessary story bits to form this statement. It's pretty straightfoward if you ask me.
Test 4 is not modified?
Ah I modified positive integer to non-negative integer in statement.
ok, thanks
